6.18.text:
Unless you've been living in an online blackout
since around 2004, you've probably at least

10.41.text:
heard of the social media site Facebook even
if you aren't one of its 1.65 billion monthly

15.31.text:
active users. Alongside rivals such as Twitter
and subsidiaries like Instagram, it's become

19.91.text:
one of the dominant means by which we communicate
with others and share our ideas.

24.09.text:
Facebook is an extremely powerful and versatile
platform, used for everything from organising

28.51.text:
events with friends and family to online activism
and political campaigning. Many have even

33.29.text:
argued that it played an important role in
organising the mass demonstrations that were

36.88.text: so vital for the 2012 Arab Spring.

39.65.text:
Yet for all its virtues, there is a worrying
trend beginning to emerge because of the way

43.58.text:
in which many Western societies utilise sites
such as Facebook to share and discuss ideas.

48.64.text:
The internet was founded on the notions of
free information and open discussion, but

52.50.text:
in many cases Facebook is causing the direct
opposite. The United Kingdom's reaction online

57.22.text:
to the results of the Brexit Referendum, in
which we decided whether or not the UK should

60.84.text:
remain as part of the European Union, is a
prime example of the 'echo chamber' effect

65.09.text: and the damage it can cause.

67.18.text:
What is an 'echo chamber'? To answer, we must
turn back to 1988, when French sociologist

72.44.text:
Michel Maffesoli published a book entitled
'Le Temps des tribus', or 'The Time of the

75.89.text:
Tribes'. This is one of the earliest examples
of the idea of 'neotribalism'. In it, Maffesoli

81.67.text:
discusses the breakdown of older models of
human societies, and the natural urge we as

86.03.text:
a species have to gather together into groups
we feel a common connection with. This formation

90.86.text:
of neotribal collectives isn't without its
risks. Within groups made up entirely of those

95.57.text:
with similar notions it is all too easy to
create an 'us versus them' mentality, otherising

103.37.text:
How then, does this relate to Facebook? Well,
because Facebook is the embodiment of online

107.58.text:
neotribalism. Though Maffesoli wrote his book
before the online era, his ideas have a worrying

112.93.text:
similarity to the way in which people come
together on social media. We are naturally

117.93.text:
inclined to congregate with those who share
our opinions and worldviews, just as we are

121.82.text:
inclined to shut out and ignore those who
don't. Thus our social media circles are dominated

126.92.text:
by like-minded individuals, each sharing and
discussing the same (or at least similar)

133.47.text:
Even if you're one of those more open-minded
individuals willing to move within the social

137.07.text:
circles of those with opinions different to
your own, it doesn't matter. Facebook's algorithms

142.30.text:
are actively tracking and analysing which
links you're most likely to follow, which

146.04.text:
statuses you're inclined to like or share
more, and as a result are actively tailoring

150.49.text:
your timeline feeds based on this information.
This is an effect known as the “Facebook

156.67.text:
In short, dissenting and alternate ideas are
being removed from Facebook, either consciously

162.11.text:
by its users or indirectly by the filter bubble.
We are only able to hear what we want to hear.

168.68.text:
The damage this can do to our perspective
of the world is serious. A tailored, edited

173.50.text:
outlook of the world is not accurate to reality,
but if its all you have experienced for a

177.67.text:
long time it may well become how you perceive
it. If you believe X, and everyone you know

182.70.text:
believes X, and every news source you come
across states X, then it will seem very likely

186.98.text:
to you that X is correct and anyone who thinks
Y is very obviously incorrect. This makes

192.51.text:
it all too easy to otherise anyone who thinks
Y; they're misinformed, delusional, or lacking

199.30.text:
But how does this all relate to Brexit? Well,
our online social echo-chambers, the media

204.43.text:
we consume and the way it is presented to
us, has resulted in a great number of us falling

208.76.text:
under the impression that the Remain vote
was quite definitely going to win, despite

212.86.text:
all the evidence of how close an election
it was going to be. It helps to explain the

217.31.text:
utter shock of so many, on both sides of the
debate, to wake up on Friday 24th and discover

222.55.text:
that Leave had in fact narrowly won, an outcome
we had conditioned ourselves to think was

228.79.text:
The otherisation, and outright demonisation,
of those who voted to Leave the EU has become

233.54.text:
increasingly worrisome even just in the brief
period after the referendum. Journalists daring

238.81.text:
to speak out in favour of the vote are being
asked to apologise for racist attacks across

242.89.text:
the country, and Leave voters are being lumped
together as xenophobic bigots despite the

247.25.text:
myriad of reasons they had for voting the
way they did. This is dangerous, creating

252.21.text:
divisions and stoking the fire for horrendously
undemocratic notions of a second referendum

257.08.text:
or even having parliament ignore it entirely;
whether we are happy with the result or not,

261.93.text:
it is vital that we accept that it has happened
and move forward from there.

266.11.text:
In trying times we must still acknowledge
the legitimacy of differing opinions, even

270.19.text:
if we wholly disagree with them. The alternative
is shutting out conflicting opinions and listening

275.12.text:
only to those who agree with us, an action
that creates only stagnation and a distorted

279.73.text:
view of the world. If there is a lesson to
be learned from the Brexit campaigns online,

284.26.text:
it's the importance of communication and open,
honest discussion; Facebook doesn't have to

288.95.text:
be an echo chamber if we don't allow it to
be.

291.54.text:
Read widely, consider articles you wouldn't
normally, share them with your friends even

295.72.text:
if you don't agree with them; stimulating
debate is vital in times such as these. Facebook

301.35.text:
doesn't have to be a neotribal echo-chamber;
it still could live up to the aspirations

306.02.text:
and hopes on which it (and the internet as
a whole) was founded, of an open forum for
